subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Book suggestions for translation.
msgSnippet: ... The Universal Character Set encodes characters , not graphemes . ... characters ... This is incorrect. I consider Quickscript to be a set of extensions
messageBody:
On 30 Jul 2011, at 10:22, peter_r_guinness wrote:

> The unicode standard was designed with future expansion in mind and so was made from the start to potentially handle *lots* of graphemes--

The Universal Character Set encodes "characters", not "graphemes".

> all the world's current symbols

"characters"

> in all its traditional writing systems can fit comfortably into it with plenty of room left to spare.
>
> Because Quickscript is not a traditional alphabet it was never included formally into unicode--

This is incorrect. I consider Quickscript to be a set of extensions to Shavian. Some preliminary work has been done working out what the extensions might be, but the activity was not followed through on, likely because people got interested in other things.

> however, the unicode people realised that there will be odd-ball and new alphabets like this and left aside room for them in a special area (ie: they left aside a range of numbers for these types of alphabets).

This is not correct. There is no "area" for either "odd-ball" or "new" alphabets. Usage dictates what gets encoded.

> The ordering of alphabets in the area are not controlled by unicode-- its a free-for-all: anyone can place their own alphabet whereever they like in this area.

Oh. You're talking about the Private Use Area. You might have said so. In any case, the Private Use Area is not intended for any particular purpose: it is not reserved for "odd-ball" or "new" alphabets.

> This means that some of these alphabets may collide with others-- there is a voluntary non-official group which sort-of polices this area and offers guidance/control where people should place their own alphabets.

I guess you mean me and John.

> (Indeed-- if I'm not mistaken John Cowan of this group or formerly of this group-- don't know if he's still active-- has had a *lot* to do with maintaining the order in this region of unicode.)

The CSUR is not a formal or informal part of the Unicode Standard.

> If QS alphabet is ever formerly accepted into unicode then it will be given its own unique special region with-in unicode.

No, it will be encoded as a set of extensions to Shavian.

> * Unicode is actually a bit more complicated then this and contains other info besides just raw mapping of graphemes.

The standard encodes "characters", not "graphemes".

Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com/
